choices.text: Annular hymen

questions.text: Identify the type of hymen shown in the image? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Septate hymen

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given image is suggestive of the septate hymen.
  • The hymen is the membranous vestige of the junction between the sino-vaginal bulbs and the urogenital sinus, which perforates during fetal life to establish a connection between the vaginal lumen and the perineum.
  • Defective perforation of this structure may result in the following variants of hymen:
    • Imperforate hymen: Without any opening (presents as cryptomenorrhea at puberty)
    • Micro-perforate hymen: Tiny opening
    • Annular hymen: Oval central opening
    • Septate hymen: Two lateral openings partitioned by a bridge of hymenal tissue (May have difficulty in intercourse, placement of a tampon)
    • Naviculate hymen: Boat-like opening

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Imperforate hymen: An imperforate hymen has no opening at all and often presents as cryptomenorrhea (accumulation of menstrual blood behind the hymen) at puberty.

 

Option B. Semilunar hymen: A semilunar hymen has a crescent-shaped opening and is not depicted in the image.

 

Option D. Annular hymen: An annular hymen has an oval central opening and does not match the septate appearance in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A septate hymen is characterized by two lateral openings partitioned by a bridge of hymenal tissue, which may lead to difficulties with intercourse or tampon use.

 

 

Ref: Page no 18, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text:
Consider the following actions under AMTSL. Arrange them in the right order? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Uterine tone assessment
  2. Give uterotonic (oxytocin 10 mg)
  3. Exclude the presence of another fetus
  4. Controlled cord traction

 

AMTSL- Active management of the third stage of labor.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3, 2, 4, 1

 

Active Management of 3rd Stage of Labor

 

Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) is a set of interventions aimed at preventing postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). The correct order of actions is:

 

3. Exclude the presence of another fetus: Ensure there is no additional fetus before administering any uterotonic.

 

2. Give uterotonic (oxytocin 10 mg): Administer a uterotonic drug to help the uterus contract and reduce bleeding. It is given after the delivery of baby.

 

4. Controlled cord traction: Perform controlled traction on the umbilical cord to deliver the placenta.

 

1. Uterine tone assessment: assess the uterine tone every 15 minutes to detect uterine atony.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The steps of Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) should be followed in a specific order: exclude the presence of another fetus, administer a uterotonic, perform controlled cord traction, and then assess the uterine tone.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions, hysteroscopy can be done? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asherman syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Hysteroscopy is the treatment of choice in Asherman syndrome.

 

Asherman Syndrome

 

  • These are intra-uterine adhesions
  • They usually follow a history of sharp curettage
  • Symptoms are hypomenorrhea, secondary amenorrhoea and secondary infertility

 

Diagnosis –

 

TVS: broken/ irregular endometrium

 

HSG: space filling defect is seen (moth eaten appearance)

 

Ix of choice: Hysteroscopy

 

Treatment - Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubal ligation: Tubal ligation is done via laparoscopy.

 

Option C. Endocervical polyp: In Endocervical polyps’ cases surgical ligation and excision can be done if severe bleeding is expected. Hysteroscopy can help visualisation and assessment but it is not the primary method for managing endocervical polyps.

 

Option D. Subserosal fibroid: In cases of Subserosal fibroids an MRI helps in detailed mapping of the fibroids if a myomectomy is planned.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hysteroscopy is the treatment of choice in Asherman syndrome.

choices.text: At eight weeks the embryo is bipotent
Wolffian duct develops into epididymis and vas deferens on either side of the body
Mullerian inhibiting substance inhibits mullerian duct
Dihydrotestosterone leads to the development of secondary sexual characters and external genitalia

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about male sexual development? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) At eight weeks the embryo is bipotent

 

Explanation:

 

At eight weeks of gestation, the embryo is no longer bipotent. The term "bipotent" refers to the embryo's capability to develop into either male or female structures, which is true up until about the sixth week of development. By the eighth week, sexual differentiation is already underway, with the influence of the SRY gene causing the gonads to differentiate into testes in 46XY embryos. This differentiation results in a shift away from bipotency, making the embryo committed to developing male characteristics.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Wolffian duct develops into epididymis and vas deferens on either side of the body: This statement is true. The Wolffian ducts, under the influence of testosterone, develop into the male reproductive structures including the epididymis and vas deferens.

 

Option C. Mullerian inhibiting substance inhibits Mullerian duct: This statement is true. Mullerian inhibiting substance (MIS), also known as anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH), is produced by Sertoli cells in the testes and inhibits the development of the Mullerian ducts, which would otherwise develop into female reproductive structures such as the uterine tubes and uterus.

 

Option D. Dihydrotestosterone leads to the development of secondary sexual characters and external genitalia: This statement is true. Dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a potent metabolite of testosterone, is crucial for the development of male external genitalia and secondary sexual characteristics such as facial hair and a deeper voice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At eight weeks of gestation, the embryo is no longer bipotent; sexual differentiation has already commenced.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman on oral contraceptives for the past 6 months presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea. What would be the best method of assessing the gestational age of this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Crown rump length by USG

 

Explanation:

 

Crown-Rump Length (CRL) by Ultrasound:

 

  • The most accurate method for determining gestational age in the first trimester is by measuring the Crown-Rump Length (CRL) on ultrasound. This method is reliable as it directly measures the embryo or fetus and provides a precise gestational age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adding 280 days to the Last Menstrual Period (LMP):

 

  • This method, known as Naegele’s rule, is commonly used but assumes a regular 28-day menstrual cycle and may not be accurate for women with irregular cycles or those using contraceptives.
  • It is less reliable in this patient who has been on oral contraceptives, which can alter the regularity of menstrual cycles.

 

Option C. Fundus Examination:

 

  • Palpation of the uterine fundus is a physical examination method to estimate gestational age. However, it is less accurate in the first trimester and typically used in the second and third trimesters.

 

Option D. Adding 256 days to the LMP:

 

  • This method is not standard practice and is less commonly used compared to adding 280 days to the LMP.
  • It would be even less reliable in this patient who has been on oral contraceptives.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most accurate method for determining gestational age in the first trimester is the measurement of Crown-Rump Length (CRL) on ultrasound.

 

Ref: Page no 475, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 22y type 1 DM is in the post operative ward following a cesarean done for failed induction (for preeclampsia with severe features). She complains of drowsiness and altered sensorium. She is on maintenance MgSO4 infusion and on IV infusion of insulin. On examination, her PR is 70/ min. BP is 140/ 98 mmHg. RR is 10/min. Auscultation of lungs reveals bilateral normal air entry. Abdominal examination reveals a firm uterus with normal tenderness. Pfannenstiel scar is intact and there is no significant vaginal bleeding. B/l patellar reflexes are absent. A urine dipstick for protein and sugar is negative and a capillary glucose sample is 270 mg%. The suspected diagnosis is? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Magnesium sulphate toxicity

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given clinical scenario and examination finding of B/L absent knee reflex and respiratory depression following magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) administration for preeclampsia suggest the cause of her condition to be magnesium sulfate toxicity.
  • MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia.
  • The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L
  • When on MgSO4, patients must be monitored for magnesium toxicity:
  • A woman on MgSO4 for management of eclampsia requires the following to be checked for Mg toxicity:
    1. Deep tendon reflexes
    2. Respiratory Rate
    3. Urine Output
  • Magnesium toxicity occurs at these levels
    • At > 7-10 mEq/L: Loss of DTR
    • 10 - 12 mEq/L: Respiratory depression
    • 25 mEq/L: Cardiac arrest
  • Antidote for Mg toxicity: Ca gluconate (1 g IV)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diabetic ketoacidosis: This is unlikely as urine for sugars is absent.

 

Option C. Postpartum eclampsia: This is unlikely as there is no history of seizures

 

Option D. Peripartum cardiomyopathy: There is no evidence of cardiac failure and hence this is also unlikely

 

Educational Objective:

 

When administering magnesium sulfate for preeclampsia, it is critical to monitor for signs of magnesium toxicity, which include loss of deep tendon reflexes, respiratory depression, and cardiac arrest. The antidote for magnesium toxicity is calcium gluconate.

 

Ref: Page no 1860, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

choices.text: Hypertension diagnosed at 10 weeks of gestation

questions.text: Pregnant women with which of the following is called systemic hypertension? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypertension diagnosed at 10 weeks of gestation

 

Explanation:

 

Systemic hypertension in pregnancy is classified as chronic hypertension if it is diagnosed in the first trimester or if hypertension persists beyond 12 weeks postpartum. Hypertension present before pregnancy or diagnosed before the 20th week of gestation also qualifies as chronic hypertension. This is distinct from gestational hypertension, which develops after 20 weeks of gestation in a previously normotensive woman.

 

  • Chronic Hypertension: Defined as blood pressure of ≥ 140/90 mm Hg that was present before pregnancy or diagnosed before the 20th week of gestation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diabetic retinopathy: This condition is a complication of diabetes affecting the eyes, not a direct indicator of systemic hypertension.

 

Option C. Diabetic nephropathy: This is a complication of diabetes that affects the kidneys and can be associated with hypertension, but it is not specific to the definition of systemic hypertension in pregnancy.

 

Option D. Episode of seizure: Seizures in the context of pregnancy are associated with eclampsia, a severe form of preeclampsia, but do not directly define systemic hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Systemic hypertension in pregnancy is diagnosed if high blood pressure is present before pregnancy, is diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation, or persists beyond 12 weeks postpartum.

 

Ref: Page no 1778, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Banana sign and lemon sign are seen in? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NTD

 

Banana sign and lemon sign are ultrasound findings typically associated with neural tube defects (NTD), more specifically spina bifida.

 

  • Banana sign: This refers to the excessive curvature of the cerebellum, which appears compressed and curved, resembling a banana.
  • Lemon sign: This is characterized by the pinching of the frontal bones of the fetal skull, causing it to appear like a lemon when viewed from the front. These signs are indicative of the changes in intracranial pressure and structure caused by spina bifida.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anencephaly: This condition involves the absence of a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp, and is often described as having a "frog-like" face due to the absence of the cranial vault.

 

Option C. Down syndrome: Down syndrome has various ultrasound markers, but these are typically subtle and referred to as soft tissue markers, not including the banana or lemon signs.

 

Option D. Duodenal atresia: This condition is characterized by the "double bubble" sign on ultrasound, indicating a blockage in the duodenum, and is not associated with the banana or lemon signs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Banana sign and lemon sign are ultrasound findings seen in neural tube defects (NTD), particularly in cases of spina bifida.

questions.text: A patient came to the gynecology OPD with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge and intense itching. On examination, the cervix was spotted and had the appearance of a strawberry. Identify the causative organism? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichomonas vaginalis

 

  • Intense vaginal itching and foul-smelling greenish discharge are suggestive of Trichomonas vaginalis infection.
  • Strawberry like appearance of the cervix helps in establishing the diagnosis.
  • On vaginal smear, flagellated organism (T. vaginalis is seen)

 

Other Options:

 

Best understood by this table given below

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichomonas vaginalis infection is characterized by foul-smelling, frothy yellowish-green discharge and a strawberry-like appearance of the cervix.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Laparoscopic ovarian drilling

questions.text: All of the following can be used for the treatment of PCOD except? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ulipristal

 

Explanation:

 

  • Ulipristal is not used for the treatment of PCOD.
    • It is a selective progesterone receptor modulator.
    • It is used as an emergency contraceptive and in medical management of fibroids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clomiphene: Clomiphene is an anti-estrogen used in ovulation induction in women with PCOS (1st line agent) and infertility

 

  • Gonadotropins can also be used in PCOS with infertility in those who have clomiphene resistance (2nd line therapy)

 

Option B. Letrozole: But nowadays Letrozole (aromatase inhibitor) is the drug for ovulation induction in PCOS with infertility.

 

Option D. Laparoscopic ovarian drilling: It is recommended as second-line therapy in PCOS

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulipristal is not used for the treatment of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS). It is a selective progesterone receptor modulator primarily used for emergency contraception and managing uterine fibroids.

 

Ref: Page 244, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Blighted ovum
﻿﻿﻿Missed abortion
﻿﻿﻿Ectopic pregnancy

questions.text: A primigravida in her 10th week of gestation presents with spotting. On examination, the uterus corresponds to 12 weeks. Transvaginal ultrasound was done and it is given below. What is your diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hydatidiform mole

 

Explanation:


The typical ‘Snowstorm appearance’ on ultrasound is indicative of a hydatidiform mole. This appearance is characteristic of a complete molar pregnancy, where there is a proliferation of abnormal tissue instead of a viable embryo.

 

  • Complete Mole:
    • Ultrasound Finding: Snowstorm appearance with diffuse, heterogeneous echogenicity.
    • Genetics: Diploid with only paternal genetic material. It can occur due to either:
      • One sperm fertilizing an empty or inactivated ovum (androgenesis), leading to 46XX or 46XY.
      • Two sperm fertilizing an empty ovum (dispermy), also leading to 46XX or 46XY.
    • Clinical Management: Suction evacuation is the standard treatment.
  • Partial Mole:
    • Genetics: Triploid, with 69XXX or 69XXY, resulting from two sperm fertilizing one ovum.
    • Clinical Appearance: Typically has a more complex presentation with an abnormal fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blighted ovum: Also known as an anembryonic pregnancy, this occurs when a gestational sac forms but no embryo is visible. It does not present with the Snowstorm appearance and usually lacks the pronounced proliferation of tissue seen in a hydatidiform mole.

 

Option B. Missed abortion: This involves the retention of an embryo or fetus with no detectable heartbeat or growth. The ultrasound findings typically show a non-viable fetus without the characteristic snowstorm pattern of a hydatidiform mole.

 

Option C. Ectopic pregnancy: This occurs when a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, often in the fallopian tubes. It would not present with the Snowstorm appearance but rather show a gestational sac or products of conception in an abnormal location.

 

Educational Objective:


The 'Snowstorm appearance' on transvaginal ultrasound is characteristic of a hydatidiform mole.

 

Ref: Page no 225, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Marker for ectopic pregnancy is? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta hCG

 

The correct answer is Beta hCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin). Beta hCG is a hormone produced by the placenta during pregnancy. In the context of an ectopic pregnancy, which is a pregnancy located outside the uterine cavity (commonly in the fallopian tubes), the measurement of Beta hCG levels is crucial for diagnosis and management.

 

Beta hCG: In a normal intrauterine pregnancy, Beta hCG levels typically double every 48-72 hours. In ectopic pregnancies, these levels usually rise more slowly. Additionally, Beta hCG levels are used to determine the mode of management for unruptured ectopic pregnancies (medical, surgical, or expectant management) and to assess the discriminatory zone, which is the level of Beta hCG at which an intrauterine pregnancy should be visible on ultrasound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Estradiol: This is a form of estrogen, a hormone involved in the regulation of the menstrual cycle and pregnancy, but it is not a marker for ectopic pregnancy.

 

Option C. Progesterone: This hormone supports the early stages of pregnancy by preparing the uterine lining for implantation, but it is not specifically used to diagnose ectopic pregnancy.

 

Option D. Estriol: Another form of estrogen produced during pregnancy, it is not used as a marker for ectopic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta hCG is the primary marker used to diagnose and manage ectopic pregnancies, providing essential information about pregnancy location and viability.

choices.text: Wait and watch for 4 weeks
Repeat TVS after one week
Serum HCG levels

questions.text: A lady with 7 weeks amenorrhea presented with slight vaginal spotting. Crown Rump Length was 5 mm with a well-formed gestational sac with a calculated gestational age of 5.6 weeks on TVS. What is the next line of management? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Repeat TVS after one week

 

In the case described, the patient has a gestational sac and a crown-rump length (CRL) of 5 mm, with a calculated gestational age of 5.6 weeks based on transvaginal sonography (TVS). The guidelines for assessing early pregnancy viability are:

 

  • Absence of an embryo at a mean sac diameter (MSD) ≥ 25 mm indicates an anembryonic pregnancy.
  • Absence of cardiac activity at a CRL ≥ 7 mm indicates a non-viable pregnancy.

 

In this scenario, the CRL is 5 mm, which is below the threshold where the absence of cardiac activity would indicate a non-viable pregnancy (≥ 7 mm). There is no mention of cardiac activity in the current ultrasound findings, so it is crucial to monitor the pregnancy further before making any conclusions.

 

The best course of action is to repeat the transvaginal ultrasound after one week to check for the presence of cardiac activity and further development of the embryo. This approach allows for a more accurate assessment of the viability of the pregnancy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Wait and watch for 4 weeks: Waiting for 4 weeks without further evaluation could delay necessary medical intervention and is not recommended for timely assessment of pregnancy viability.

 

Option C. Serum HCG levels: While measuring serum HCG levels can provide some information about the progression of the pregnancy, it is less specific than ultrasound for determining viability, particularly in the context of assessing cardiac activity.

 

Option D. Medical intervention: Immediate medical intervention is not warranted at this stage without further evidence. The repeat ultrasound will provide more clarity on whether intervention is needed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In early pregnancy with a CRL of less than 7 mm and no documented cardiac activity, the best approach is to repeat the transvaginal ultrasound after one week to reassess for the presence of cardiac activity and viability of the pregnancy.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 645

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. Drug of choice to treat this condition is? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metronidazole

 

Explanation:


The patient presents with foul-smelling vaginal discharge, which is a common symptom of bacterial vaginosis (BV). In bacterial vaginosis, the correct treatment is Metronidazole.

 

  • Bacterial vaginosis is often caused by an imbalance in the normal bacterial flora of the vagina, commonly involving Gardnerella vaginalis. The condition is diagnosed using Amsel's Criteria, which include:
    1. Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge: The discharge is typically thin and white, and may have a fishy odor.
    2. pH of Vaginal fluid > 4.5: This elevated pH level is higher than the normal acidic environment of the vagina.
    3. Fishy odor of discharge on adding 10% KOH (Whiff test): The discharge develops a characteristic fishy odor when mixed with potassium hydroxide.
    4. Presence of Clue cells on microscopy: Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells that have a stippled appearance due to adherence of bacteria.

 

Metronidazole is the first-line treatment for bacterial vaginosis, and it is typically administered as oral tablets (500 mg twice daily for 7 days).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Clindamycin: While Clindamycin can be used to treat bacterial vaginosis, it is generally not the first choice. Metronidazole is preferred due to its effectiveness and established use.

 

Option C. Cotrimoxazole: This antibiotic is used for a variety of bacterial infections but is not effective for bacterial vaginosis.

 

Option D. Azithromycin: This is a macrolide antibiotic used primarily for sexually transmitted infections such as chlamydia and is not used for bacterial vaginosis.

 

Educational Objective:


The drug of choice for treating bacterial vaginosis is Metronidazole.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: You discover that there is evidence of cardiac malformation in a fetus during a routine US scan at 16 weeks. What is the minimum level of fasting blood sugar at which you can suspect overt diabetes? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 126 mg/dL

 

Overt diabetes in a patient is diagnosed based on specific blood glucose levels. The criteria for diagnosing overt diabetes are:

 

  • Fasting blood sugar: ≥ 126 mg/dL
  • Random blood sugar: ≥ 200 mg/dL
  • HbA1c: ≥ 6.5%

 

During pregnancy, maternal hyperglycemia, especially during the first trimester when organogenesis occurs, increases the risk of fetal congenital malformations, including cardiac malformations. This is particularly true for women with pre-gestational diabetes, not gestational diabetes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 106 mg/dL: This is incorrect. A fasting blood sugar level of 106 mg/dL does not meet the threshold for diagnosing overt diabetes.

 

Option C. 116 mg/dL: This is incorrect. A fasting blood sugar level of 116 mg/dL is higher than normal but still below the threshold for diagnosing overt diabetes.

 

Option D. 130 mg/dL: This is incorrect. Although higher than the threshold, the minimum level to suspect overt diabetes is 126 mg/dL, not 130 mg/dL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Overt diabetes in pregnancy is diagnosed with a fasting blood sugar level of ≥ 126 mg/dL, and maternal hyperglycemia.

questions.text: Immediately following the delivery, the uterus will correspond to how many weeks of gestational age? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 20 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Immediately after delivery, the uterus contracts and shrinks in size, positioning itself just below the umbilicus. This position is equivalent to the uterus at around 20 weeks of gestation.

 

The uterus's rapid involution postpartum helps in controlling bleeding and facilitating the return to its non-pregnant state.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immediately after delivery, the uterus corresponds to the size and position of a 20-week gestation, lying just below the umbilicus.

questions.text: Quadruple testing is done during? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 15-20 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Quadruple testing, also known as the quadruple screen or quad screen, is typically performed between 15-20 weeks of pregnancy, with the most accurate results obtained between 16-18 weeks. The test measures four serum analytes:

 

  • Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP)
  • Unconjugated estriol (uE3)
  • Free Beta-hCG
  • Inhibin-A

 

This test helps assess the risk of certain chromosomal abnormalities such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21) and trisomy 18, as well as neural tube defects. The quad screen has a lower sensitivity compared to the first trimester combined screening (which includes nuchal translucency and dual marker screening), making it particularly useful for women who present for prenatal care later in pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 9-11 weeks: This timeframe is generally used for first trimester screening tests, such as the combined screening, which includes nuchal translucency and the dual marker test (free β-hCG and PAPP-A).

 

Option B. 12-14 weeks: This period is also used for the combined first trimester screening but is not appropriate for the quad screen.

 

Option D. 22-28 weeks: This period is outside the recommended timeframe for the quad screen. Tests in this period are more focused on gestational diabetes screening and routine ultrasounds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The quadruple test is performed between 15-20 weeks of pregnancy to screen for chromosomal abnormalities and neural tube defects.

 

 

Easy to remember: In Down Syndrome, Beta hCG and Inhibin A are increases (B – Big; B in Beta hCG, B in Inhibin A)

 

*King Edward Abdicated his throne so all levels are decreased

questions.text: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most useful in which of the following gynecological malignancies? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carcinoma vulva

 

Sentinel lymph node biopsy is particularly useful in the management of vulval carcinomas among gynecological malignancies. The technique helps in determining the extent of lymph node involvement and thereby reduces unnecessary lymph node dissections and their associated complications, such as lymphedema. Sentinel lymph node biopsy can effectively identify the first lymph node (sentinel node) that drains the primary tumor, which is likely to be the first site of metastasis.

 

  • Lymphatic Mapping and Sentinel Node Biopsy:
    • Intraoperative Injection: Intradermal injection of blue dye around the tumor to map lymphatic drainage.
    • Radioactive Tracer: Labeling tissues with a radioactive tracer and localizing with a hand-held detector.
    • Lymphoscintigraphy: This imaging technique has a 100% detection rate for sentinel lymph nodes.
  • Utility in Other Malignancies:
    • Breast carcinoma
    • Penile carcinoma
    • Malignant melanoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoma vagina: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is less commonly used in vaginal cancer compared to vulvar cancer.

 

Option C. Carcinoma cervix: While sentinel lymph node biopsy can be used, it is more established and routinely applied in vulvar cancer.

 

Option D. Carcinoma endometrium: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is also useful but not as prominently used as in vulvar carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sentinel lymph node biopsy is most useful in vulvar carcinoma among gynecological malignancies to reduce unnecessary lymph node dissection and its complications.

 

Ref: Page no 608, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has chosen to undergo vasectomy. What advice will you give this patient regarding the use of contraception post-vasectomy? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 12 – 16 weeks

 

After undergoing a vasectomy, it is important to understand that while the procedure is highly effective at preventing pregnancy, it is not immediately effective. Sperm can still be present in the reproductive system for some time following the surgery. Therefore, it is crucial to use an alternative form of contraception until a follow-up test confirms that there are no longer any viable sperm present. It is estimated that this sterilization technique is effective after about 3 months or 20 ejaculates to empty the stored semen. A semen analysis report confirming azoospermia is essential to confirm this.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After a vasectomy, alternative contraception should be used until a semen analysis confirms azoospermia, usually around 12-16 weeks post-surgery.

 

Ref: Dutta textbook of obstetrics page 32

questions.text: All are the members of the medical board in MTP > 24 weeks, except? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Legal advisor

 

For medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) after 24 weeks, especially in cases of substantial fetal anomalies, a medical board is constituted. This board typically includes specialists relevant to the condition and the required medical care. The standard members include: Radiologist, Gynecologist and Pediatrician.

 

A legal advisor is not a part of this medical board, as the board's purpose is to provide medical, not legal, expertise. The fourth member is often a specialist relevant to the detected anomaly rather than a legal professional.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiologist: Included to assess fetal abnormalities through imaging and provide critical information about the anomaly.

 

Option B. Gynecologist: A core member who handles the MTP procedure and provides obstetric and gynecological care.

 

Option D. Pediatrician: Included to give an opinion on the implications of fetal anomalies and expected postnatal outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In MTP cases beyond 24 weeks, the medical board consists of medical professionals such as radiologists, gynecologists, and pediatricians, but not legal advisors.

choices.text: Twin to Twin Transfusion Syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy
﻿﻿﻿Monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancy
﻿﻿﻿Dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy

questions.text: Identify this condition? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a monochorionic monoamniotic placenta, characterized by a single placenta with two umbilical cords and no intervening membrane. Monochorionic monoamniotic twins share both a chorion and an amniotic sac. This type of twinning occurs when the inner cell mass divides between days 8 to 12 of gestation, after the formation of the trophoblast, leading to a monochorionic condition.

 

Monochorionic monoamniotic twin gestations have a high fetal death rate due to several complications:

 

  • Preterm birth
  • Congenital anomalies
  • Low birth weight
  • Cord entanglement

 

The best time for delivery of monochorionic monoamniotic twins is between 32-34 weeks via Caesarean section.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Twin to Twin Transfusion Syndrome: This is a complication seen in monochorionic twin pregnancies. It involves a donor twin and a recipient twin. The donor twin is anemic, growth-restricted, and has oligohydramnios, while the recipient twin is polycythemic, has polyhydramnios, and suffers from circulatory overload.

 

Option B. Monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy: In this type of pregnancy, there are two amniotic cavities and one chorion. This occurs when the inner cell mass divides between 4-7 days of gestation.

 

Option D. Dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy: This pregnancy type involves two amniotic cavities and two chorions. It occurs when the inner cell mass divides between 0-3 days of gestation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancies involve a single placenta with two umbilical cords and no intervening membrane, occurring when the inner cell mass divides between days 8 to 12 of gestation.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition pg 233-234,

questions.text: Who will give permission for MTP for a woman who is mentally unsound? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Legal guardian

 

Explanation:

 

For a woman who is mentally unsound, the permission for Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) cannot be given by herself due to her compromised mental state. The legal requirement is that the consent must come from her legal guardian. A legal guardian is an individual who has been legally appointed to care for and make decisions on behalf of the mentally unsound person. This guardian may be a parent or another individual assigned by the court, but the key requirement is that the guardian must have legal authority to make such decisions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Self: A mentally unsound woman is not legally capable of giving consent for MTP due to her compromised mental state.

 

Option B. Partner: While a partner may be involved in the decision-making process, they do not have the legal authority to give permission for MTP unless they are also the legal guardian.

 

Option C. Parent: Although a parent might be a legal guardian, simply being a parent does not automatically grant the authority. The person must be legally recognized as the guardian.

 

Educational objective:

 

The legal guardian must give permission for MTP for a woman who is mentally unsound, ensuring that the decision is made in the best interest of the patient.

choices.text: Immunosuppression can be continued during pregnancy
Pregnancy to be planned once the disease has been quiescent for at least 6 months and there is no evidence of renal dysfunction
High dose corticosteroids for lupus flare in pregnancy is safe
Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, azathioprine are safe in pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about lupus nephritis in pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ecospirin, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, azathioprine are safe in pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

  • SLE is a chronic autoimmune disorder involving the multisystem. It affects young women of childbearing age. The renal involvement of the disease can manifest in the form of active lupus nephritis or flare-ups during pregnancy.
  • It can lead to preterm births, preeclampsia, and pregnancy loss while the infant can suffer from neonatal lupus and heart block.
  • Management includes
  • Preconceptionally counseling: Conception during a period of quiescence for at least 6 months determines a successful outcome. Stable remission of renal disease for at least 6 months before conception is recommended.
  • Corticosteroids are useful during episodes of lupus flare and can be used safely in pregnancy.
  • Immunosuppressants such as azathioprine can be continued during pregnancy. It may be used in case of severe SLE
  • Hydroxychloroquine is found to be the best for maintenance and is safe in pregnancy. It can prevent the need for prolonged corticosteroid therapy.
  • Methotrexate and cyclophosphamide are teratogenic and hence they are not safe during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immunosuppression can be continued during pregnancy: Correct. Medications like azathioprine can be continued under medical guidance, while others are used cautiously.

 

Option B. Pregnancy to be planned once the disease has been quiescent for at least 6 months and there is no evidence of renal dysfunction: Correct. Quiescence of the disease and stable renal function are crucial for a successful pregnancy outcome.

 

Option C. High dose corticosteroids for lupus flare in pregnancy is safe: Correct. High doses of corticosteroids can be used during a lupus flare, but must be carefully monitored.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate and cyclophosphamide are not safe during pregnancy for managing lupus nephritis; corticosteroids and azathioprine are safer options.

 

Ref: Page 2895, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Superficial transverse perineal

questions.text: The deepest part of perineal body injury, which causes cystocele, enterocoele and urethral descent is? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pubococcygeus

 

Explanation:

 

  • Pubococcygeus is the deepest part of the levator ani muscle.
  • Injury to it can cause enterocele, cystocele, and urethral descent.
  • The levator ani muscles are the most important muscles in the pelvic floor and maintain a constant state of contraction.
  • Weakening of this muscle decreases support for the vagina, bladder, uterus, or rectum or alter the position of the neck of the bladder and urethra.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bulbospongiosus, Option C. ischiocavernosus and Option D. superficial transverse perineal are all superficial muscles and their damage does not result in uterovaginal descent

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Supports of the vagal have been described by Delancey as shown below and defects in these lead to different levels of uterovaginal prolapse
    • Defect in Level 1 support: Vaginal apical prolapse and uterine prolapse
    • Defect in level 2 support: Cystocele and Rectocele
    • Defect in level 3 support: urethrocele and deficient perineal body

 

 

Ref: Page no 544, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex, and tell the mother.
Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex but don’t tell the mother.
Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, don’t check the sex.
Don’t do ultrasound, do ANC only.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G5L4 with all 4-girl children presents at 18 weeks and asks for the sex of the child on ultrasound. This is her first antenatal visit. What should be done? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, don’t check the sex.


The Ans. is C because, according to the Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques (PCPNDT) Act, sex determination of the fetus is illegal and punishable by law. At 18 weeks, the primary purpose of the ultrasound is to assess gestational age and check for any fetal abnormalities as part of the anomaly scan. Checking or revealing the sex of the fetus is prohibited and carries legal consequences. Therefore, the healthcare provider should perform the ultrasound for the medical purposes it is intended for and avoid even viewing the sex of the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex, and tell the mother: is incorrect because checking the sex and informing the mother is illegal under the PCPNDT Act, and can lead to legal repercussions, including imprisonment.

 

Option B. Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex but don’t tell the mother: is also incorrect. Even looking at the fetus’s sex, regardless of whether it is disclosed, is a violation of the law and is punishable.

 

Option D. Don’t do ultrasound, do ANC only: is incorrect because the ultrasound at 18 weeks is necessary for evaluating gestational age and detecting any fetal abnormalities, which are critical aspects of prenatal care.

 

Educational Objective:


The key point to remember is that checking or revealing the sex of the fetus during an ultrasound is illegal under the PCPNDT Act. The ultrasound should only be used for assessing fetal gestational age and abnormalities.

questions.text: Identify the contraceptive shown in the given image: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Female condom

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image is of a female condom. 
  • It is made of aa synthetic nitrile sheath with one flexible polyurethane ring at each end
  • One ring is open – lies outside the vagina.
  • The closed ring is fitted under the symphysis like a diaphragm
  • Male condoms should not be used simultaneously due to friction leading to slippage of condom or tearing
  • Also offers protection against STDs

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Male Condom:

 

 

Option C. Cervical diaphragm:

 

 

Option D. Cervical Cap:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The female condom is a synthetic nitrile sheath with one flexible polyurethane ring at each end, providing contraceptive protection and protection against STDs.

 

Ref: Page n 612, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: The following instrument is used for……:  (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PAP smear

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image shown is that of Ayre's spatula which is used for preparing PAP smear.
  • It is used to scrape the squamocolumnar junction of the cervix while preparing a Pap smear.
  • A cytobrush is used to take endocervical samples
  • The smear is fixed with 95% ethanol

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. VIA: This is Visual Inspection under Acetic Acid. This is done by applying acetic acid on the cervix. Any acetowhite area is suspicious for dysplasia. It is done in low resource settings.

 

Option B. VILI: Visual inspection under Lugol Iodine: This is done by applying Lugol’s iodine on the cervix. A dysplastic area will not take up iodine. It is also done in low resource settings.

 

 

Option D. Colposcopy: This is a magnified view of the cervix. It is done in patients with abnormal pap smear/ HPV +Ve/ VIA +ve or VILI +ve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ayre's spatula is used for preparing a Pap smear by scraping cells from the cervix for cytological examination.

 

Ref: Page no 325, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Normal vaginal delivery
Forceps delivery

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the emergency room in the early stage of labor with adequate uterine contractions. On per vaginal examination, a gynecoid pelvis is felt, the membranes are ruptured, and the vertex is felt in the right occipito-posterior position. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal vaginal delivery

 

Explanation:

 

  • Normal vaginal delivery:
    • Assuming the patient has no other complications, such as fetal distress or cephalopelvic disproportion, the given features of right occipito-posterior presentation with a favorable pelvis (gynecoid) and adequate uterine contractions can be managed by normal vaginal delivery.
    • In 90% of circumstances with a favorable pelvis and strong uterine contractions, without any complications, the occipito-posterior position can undergo the mechanism of normal labor.
    • The patient can be closely monitored for the progress of normal vaginal delivery. However, if complications arise or labor stalls, alternative methods such as vacuum-assisted delivery or forceps delivery may be considered. A cesarean section would only be necessary if there were complications that prevented a safe vaginal delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Vacuum-assisted delivery is generally considered when there is prolonged second stage of labor or fetal distress. In this case, since there are no complications mentioned and the pelvis is favorable, normal vaginal delivery is the preferred option.

 

Option B. Cesarean section: A cesarean section is usually considered when there is cephalopelvic disproportion, fetal distress, or failure to progress in labor. Given the favorable conditions in this scenario, a normal vaginal delivery is feasible.

 

Option D. Forceps delivery: Forceps delivery, like vacuum-assisted delivery, is used in cases of prolonged second stage of labor or when there is a need to expedite delivery. In the absence of such complications, normal vaginal delivery is the appropriate management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right occipito-posterior presentation with a favorable pelvis and adequate uterine contractions in a primigravida can be managed by closely monitoring for a normal vaginal delivery, provided there are no complications.

 

Ref: Page 89, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: MTP for failure of contraception can be done till: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20 weeks

 

The correct answer is 20 weeks. According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Amendment Act of 2021, termination of pregnancy for the failure of contraception can be performed up to 20 weeks. The Act outlines specific requirements for performing an MTP at different stages of pregnancy:

 

  1. Up to 20 weeks: MTP can be done for various reasons, including maternal health risks, fetal anomalies, pregnancy resulting from rape, or failure of contraception. Only one doctor's opinion is required for termination within this period.
  2. 20 to 24 weeks: Requires the opinion of two doctors. The reasons include threats to maternal health, fetal anomalies, pregnancy resulting from rape, pregnancies in minors, changes in marital status (e.g., becoming a widow or divorce), humanitarian grounds (e.g., war, natural disasters), or if the woman is disabled.
  3. Beyond 24 weeks: Termination is only permitted for substantial fetal malformations and requires approval from a medical board due to the viability of the fetus at this stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the MTP Amendment Act of 2021, MTP for failure of contraception can be performed up to 20 weeks with the opinion of one doctor.

questions.text: Anti-D vaccine is not given in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intrauterine transfusion at 28 weeks

 

The Anti-D vaccine (anti-D immunoglobulin) is typically administered to prevent Rh sensitization in Rh-negative women who might be exposed to Rh-positive fetal blood. It is given to protect against the formation of anti-Rh antibodies that could affect future pregnancies. The vaccine is not given after an intrauterine transfusion because this procedure is performed to treat severe fetal anemia in cases where the mother is Rh-positive or the indirect Coombs test (ICT) is positive, indicating that the mother has already been sensitized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amniocentesis at 16 weeks: Anti-D vaccine is given after amniocentesis to prevent Rh sensitization, as the procedure can cause fetal blood to mix with maternal blood.

 

Option B. Manual removal of placenta: Anti-D vaccine is administered after manual removal of the placenta to prevent sensitization, as this procedure can result in significant feto-maternal hemorrhage.

 

Option D. MTP at 63 days: Anti-D vaccine is given after medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) to prevent Rh sensitization if the mother is Rh-negative and the fetus is Rh-positive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-D vaccine is not given after intrauterine transfusion, as this procedure is used to treat severe fetal anemia and does not require further prophylaxis against Rh sensitization.

 

Ref: Page no 919, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the Bishop score? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type of maternal pelvis

 

Explanation:

 

Bishop Score

 

  • This is a scoring system used to assess the favorability of the cervix to respond to induction of labor. 
  • A cervix that is soft in consistency, a little dilated, short in length, anteriorly placed and the station of the presenting low down will respond well to induction of labor. 
  • The Bishop score was replaced by the Modified Bishop score, wherein, the cervical effacement (in terms of percentage) was replaced by cervical length (in cm). 
  • The 5 components of the Modified Bishop score are:
    1. Cervical Dilatation
    2. Cervical length
    3. Cervical consistency
    4. Cervical Position
    5. Station of the presenting part

 

Easy to remember Mnemonic

 

B – Bishop

 

I – Effacement

 

S – Station of presenting part

 

H – Hard/ soft (consistency)

 

O – Os dilatation (cervical dilatation)

 

P – Position of the cervix
 

  • The scoring is as shown in the table.
  • Each component is scored from 0 to 3
  • The highest score is 13 and the lowest is 0
  • A favourable score is > 6. This means the patient will respond favorably to methods of induction of labor. 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Cervical length: This is a component of the Modified Bishop score, measuring the length of the cervix in centimeters.

 

Option C. Cervical position: This is a component of the Bishop score, assessing the position of the cervix relative to the vaginal canal.

 

Option D. Dilatation of cervix: This is a component of the Bishop score, measuring the extent to which the cervix has opened.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Type of maternal pelvis is not a component of the Bishop score.

 

Ref: Page no 600, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Endometrial hyperplasia

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with a lower abdominal mass and lower abdominal discomfort. On examination, the uterus appears uniformly enlarged and adnexa is free. MRI shows the presence of a myometrial cyst. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenomyosis

 

Explanation:

 

  • Adenomyosis is the presence of endometrial tissue in the myometrium. The uterus is generally uniformly enlarged up to 12-14 weeks size and can be tender on examination.
  • Investigation of choice: Ultrasound
  • On ultrasound, the following can be seen in adenomyosis:

 

 

  • Management of adenomyosis
    • Medical management: For symptomatic relief
    • Total Hysterectomy (Definitive treatment - Treatment of choice if family is complete)

 

Other options

 

Option A. Endometriosis: This presents as 5Ds (Dysmenorrhoea, Dyspareunia, Dyschezia, Dysfertility and Dull-aching abdominal pain). Diagnostic modality of choice is laparoscopy. Myometrial cysts are not seen. Endometriotic (chocolate) cysts in the ovary may be seen.

 

Option C. Leiomyoma: Fibroids or leiomyomas usually present with menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea. If very large, they will present with abdominal mass and pelvic pressure. On ultrasound, depending on the location, well circumscribed rounded lesions are seen.

 

Option D. Endometrial hyperplasia: This will present as menorrhagia. On ultrasound the endometrium will be thickened.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenomyosis is characterized by a uniformly enlarged uterus with myometrial cysts, diagnosed primarily via ultrasound.

 

Ref: Page no 196, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: According to IADPSG, what is the cut-off value of fasting blood glucose for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) > 92 mg/dL

 

Explanation:

 

The International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups (IADPSG) has established criteria for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). According to their guidelines:

 

  • The fasting blood glucose cut-off value for diagnosing GDM during a 75g oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is >92 mg/dL.

 

This value is used as part of a comprehensive assessment, including 1-hour and 2-hour postprandial glucose levels. The IADPSG criteria for GDM diagnosis include:

 

  • Fasting: ≥92 mg/dL
  • 1-hour: ≥180 mg/dL
  • 2-hour: ≥153 mg/dL

 

If any one of these values is abnormal, the diagnosis of GDM can be made.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. >95 mg/dL: This is not the IADPSG recommended cut-off for fasting blood glucose. It is higher than the specified cut-off value for diagnosing GDM.

 

Option C. >106 mg/dL: This value is significantly higher than the recommended cut-off. It exceeds the threshold for diagnosing GDM according to IADPSG guidelines.

 

Option D. >90 mg/dL: While this value is close, it is slightly below the IADPSG recommended cut-off of >92 mg/dL for diagnosing GDM.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cut-off value of fasting blood glucose for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus according to IADPSG is >92 mg/dL.

 

Ref: Page no 326, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: A patient presents at 36 weeks with chronic HTN and 3+ proteinuria. Her BP is 170/100 mmHg and she complains of headache and blurring of vision. What is the best management option? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Labetalol + MgSO4 + Expedite delivery

 

This patient is presenting with chronic hypertension that has progressed to superimposed preeclampsia, indicated by the development of 3+ proteinuria, a blood pressure of 170/100 mmHg, and symptoms such as headache and blurring of vision. These symptoms and her elevated blood pressure suggest severe preeclampsia.

 

  • Severe Preeclampsia: A systolic blood pressure greater than 160 mmHg or a diastolic blood pressure greater than 110 mmHg, along with symptoms like headache and visual disturbances, are indicators of severe preeclampsia. In this case, the patient’s condition requires urgent management to prevent the development of eclampsia, a condition that can lead to seizures and other severe complications.
  • Management: The correct management for severe preeclampsia at 36 weeks gestation includes the administration of Labetalol to lower the blood pressure, Magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) to prevent seizures, and expedited delivery to resolve the preeclampsia. After 34 weeks of gestation, delivery is recommended for severe preeclampsia because the risks of continuing the pregnancy outweigh the benefits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Labetalol + MgSO4 + Wait till 37 weeks: As this is severe preeclampsia, there is a very high risk waiting till 37 weeks. Immediate delivery is indicated after 34 weeks

 

Option C. Labetalol + Corticosteroids + wait till 37 weeks: There is no indication for corticosteroids as she has crossed 34 weeks and also there is no indication to wait till 37 weeks as this is severe preeclampsia

 

Option D. Labetalol + Corticosteroids + Expedite delivery: Although delivery needs to be expedited, there is no indication for corticosteroids as she has crossed 34 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe preeclampsia after 34 weeks, immediate delivery, blood pressure control with labetalol, and seizure prophylaxis with magnesium sulfate are essential for optimal maternal and fetal outcomes.

choices.text: Measure CA 125 levels
Follow up after 6 weeks

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman who has had 2 children through normal delivery presents with a dull aching pain over the abdomen, with irregular menses. Per vaginal examination revealed a mass felt through the posterior fornix. A USG showed a clear ovarian cyst of size 5 x 5 cm. What is the next best step? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Follow up after 6 weeks

 

A clear ovarian cyst with minimal symptoms and size less than 8 cm in a woman of reproductive age group is most likely a functional ovarian cyst. The next best step in the management of this case is to follow up after 6-12 weeks and perform a repeat USG.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Functional Ovarian Cyst: In reproductive-aged women, a clear ovarian cyst less than 8 cm is likely functional.
  • Follow-Up: The recommended management is to follow up after 6-12 weeks with a repeat ultrasound to check if the cyst resolves on its own.
  • Indications for Further Intervention: Surgical treatment is warranted if there are worrying features, the cyst is greater than 8 cm, there are significant symptoms, or CA-125 levels are raised.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measure CA 125 levels: CA 125 is a marker for epithelial ovarian tumors and is more relevant in postmenopausal women. It has limited role in premenopausal women with clear, simple cysts.

 

Option C. Laparoscopy: Surgical intervention such as laparoscopy is not immediately necessary for a 5 cm cyst unless there are concerning features or persistence after follow-up.

 

Option D. CT pelvis: CT scan is not typically indicated for initial assessment of a simple ovarian cyst detected on ultrasound.

 

Additional information:

 

  • OC Pills: Oral contraceptive pills have not been proven effective in treating simple ovarian cysts, though they are often used.
  • Simple Ovarian Cysts: Any simple ovarian cyst less than 5 cm without symptoms can be left alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a reproductive-aged woman with a clear ovarian cyst less than 8 cm and minimal symptoms, the best approach is to follow up with a repeat ultrasound after 6-12 weeks, rather than immediate intervention.

 

Ref: RCOG greentop guideline number 62 , Williams textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg217

choices.text: MTP cannot be done as she has crossed 20 weeks
MTP can be done till 24 weeks
MTP can be done only if the mother's life is at risk
MTP can only be done if there is a substantial fetal anomaly

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl, a victim of rape, presents at 22 weeks for abortion. What advice will you give her? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B)  MTP can be done till 24 weeks

 

The MTP Act of 2021 in India allows for abortions b/w 20- 24 weeks in specific cases, including:

 

  • Rape or sexual assault: The girl in the question is a victim of rape, which falls under this category.
  • Risk to maternal life or Disability: If continuing the pregnancy poses a significant risk to the mother's health or life.
  • Substantial fetal anomaly: If the fetus has severe abnormalities incompatible with life or causing significant disability.
  • Minors: The girl is 14 years old, making her a minor, and the law provides special considerations for them.
  • Change in marital status or humanitarian grounds: These are additional situations where MTP may be considered up to 24 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MTP cannot be done as she has crossed 20 weeks: This is incorrect. While the general limit for MTP is 20 weeks, certain circumstances, like rape, allow for MTP up to 24 weeks.

 

Option C. MTP can be done only if the mother's life is at risk: This is partially correct. While risk to the mother's life is a valid reason, it's not the only one. Rape is also a valid indication for MTP up to 24 weeks.

 

Option D. MTP can only be done if there is a substantial fetal anomaly: Again, this is partially correct. Substantial fetal anomaly is one reason, but rape is another valid reason for MTP up to 24 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, under the MTP Act of 2021:

choices.text: The quantity of sperms
The motility of sperms
The morphology of sperms
The number of sperm

questions.text: Identify the best parameter to assess in case of male infertility? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The morphology of sperms

 

Explanation:

 

The morphology of sperms is considered the best parameter to assess male infertility. Sperm morphology refers to the size and shape of sperm, and abnormalities in these characteristics can significantly affect a man's fertility.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Sperm Morphology: Characterization of normal sperm morphology shows improved correlation with fertilization rates during IVF cycles. A significantly decreased fertilization rate is observed when the normal morphology of the sample falls below the strict criteria of 4%.
  • Sperm Quantity and Number: While the quantity and number of sperms are important, they are not as critical as morphology in determining fertility potential.
  • Sperm Motility: Motility is also a crucial factor, but morphology has a stronger correlation with fertilization success.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The quantity of sperms: Refers to the total volume of ejaculate, which is less indicative of fertility compared to morphology.

 

Option B. The motility of sperms: Important for fertility but not as strongly correlated with fertilization success as morphology.

 

Option D. The number of sperm: Similar to the quantity, the number is important but does not correlate as closely with fertilization rates as morphology does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sperm morphology is the most significant parameter for assessing male infertility, as it closely correlates with fertilization rates during assisted reproductive techniques like IVF.

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilatation and curettage for molar pregnancy 6 months ago presents with persistent symptoms of abdominal pain and distention. On further evaluation, the beta- hCG levels were persistently elevated and cannonball foci were found on the chest X-ray. What is the appropriate management in this case? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methotrexate with folinic acid

 

Explanation:

 

Methotrexate with folinic acid: This is a clear case of post-molar choriocarcinoma with lung metastases. Treatment is based on prognostication and staging. According to the given scoring system, the parameters such as the time interval since the antecedent pregnancy, beta-hCG levels, and the presence of lung metastases suggest a low-risk choriocarcinoma. For low-risk choriocarcinoma, the recommended treatment is multi-dose single-agent chemotherapy with methotrexate. Methotrexate is administered in a multi-dose regimen (Day 1, 3, 5, 7) alternating with folinic acid (Day 2, 4, 6, 8).

 

 

  • < 6: LOW RISK
  • > 7 HIGH RISK

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Methotrexate: Methotrexate alone might be considered for very low-risk cases. However, in this case, with persistent elevated beta-hCG levels and lung metastases, a multi-dose regimen along with folinic acid is preferred to enhance efficacy and reduce toxicity.

 

Option C. EMACO regimen: The EMACO regimen, which includes etoposide, methotrexate, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, and vincristine, is used for high-risk choriocarcinoma. This patient's score indicates a low-risk profile, making EMACO unnecessary and more toxic than needed.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is not the first line of treatment for choriocarcinoma, especially in the context of low-risk metastatic disease. It may be considered in cases of heavy bleeding or when the disease is confined to the uterus and chemotherapy is not effective.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low-risk choriocarcinoma post-molar pregnancy with lung metastases is treated with a multi-dose regimen of methotrexate alternating with folinic acid

 

Ref: Page 789, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

choices.text: Amoxicillin
Fluconazole
Metronidazole

questions.text: A 25-year-old female came with complaints of greenish discharge per vagina and on examination she had a strawberry cervix. Which of the following is the treatment for her? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metronidazole

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of greenish-yellow discharge and a strawberry cervix is characteristic of trichomoniasis. Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis. The diagnostic feature of trichomoniasis includes the presence of motile flagellate organisms on a wet mount microscopy.

 

  • Characteristic findings:
    • Colour of discharge: Greenish yellow
    • On examination: Strawberry cervix and vagina
    • pH: >5
    • Diagnosis (Wet mount): Motile flagellate organism

 

Treatment:

 

  • The recommended treatment for trichomoniasis is metronidazole. It can be administered as a single dose of 2g or 200mg TDS for 7 days.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline: This antibiotic is used to treat various bacterial infections, including some sexually transmitted infections, but it is not the treatment of choice for trichomoniasis.

 

Option B. Amoxicillin: This antibiotic is used for bacterial infections but is not effective against trichomoniasis.

 

Option C. Fluconazole: This antifungal medication is used to treat candidiasis, not trichomoniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Strawberry cervix and greenish-yellow vaginal discharge are characteristic of trichomoniasis, which is treated with metronidazole.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Strawberry cervix and vagina are characteristic of Trichomoniasis

 

Ref: Page no 164, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: It can be done with the opinion of 2 doctors
It cannot be done if there is a fetal Anomaly
It requires the opinion of a medical board

questions.text: A patient presents at 22 weeks for an MTP due to failure of contraception. Which of the following is correct? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It cannot be done

 

As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Amendment Act of 2021, the upper limit for termination due to failure of contraception is 20 weeks.

 

The Act extends the permissible gestational age for termination to 24 weeks, but only in specific cases, including:

 

Fetal anomalies

 

Pregnancies resulting from rape or sexual assault

 

Maternal health risks

 

Certain socio-economic conditions (e.g., a woman becoming a widow or getting divorced after conception)

 

In this case, the patient requests MTP at 22 weeks due to failure of contraception, which is not a legally permissible indication beyond 20 weeks.

 

MTP beyond 20 weeks is only allowed for fetal anomalies and other specific conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It can be done with the opinion of 2 doctors: Incorrect because MTP beyond 20 weeks for failure of contraception is not allowed, regardless of the number of doctors.

 

Option B. It cannot be done if there is a fetal anomaly: Incorrect because MTP can be done up to 24 weeks in the presence of substantial fetal anomalies, with a board’s approval.

 

Option C. It requires the opinion of a medical board: Incorrect because a medical board is only required for MTP beyond 24 weeks for fetal anomalies or rare medical conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MTP for failure of contraception is only allowed up to 20 weeks.

 

MTP between 20-24 weeks is permitted for specific cases such as fetal anomalies, maternal health risks, and pregnancies due to sexual assault.

 

Beyond 24 weeks, termination requires the approval of a medical board for severe fetal anomalies.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of puberty menorrhagia? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anovulation

 

Explanation:

 

Anovulation is the most common cause of puberty menorrhagia. Menorrhagia refers to heavy menstrual bleeding that occurs in a regular cycle. In adolescents, anovulation, which is the failure of the ovary to release an oocyte during a menstrual cycle, frequently leads to heavy or prolonged bleeding due to the lack of a normal hormonal cycle that regulates the endometrial lining. Without the usual cyclical hormonal fluctuations, the endometrial lining may become excessively thick, leading to heavy bleeding when it sheds. This condition is typical in puberty due to the body's ongoing adjustment to hormonal regulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endometriosis: Endometriosis involves the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, which can cause painful menstruation and potentially contribute to menorrhagia. However, it is less common than anovulation as the primary cause of menorrhagia in adolescents.

 

Option C. Malignancy: Malignancy is a rare cause of menorrhagia in puberty. While malignancy can lead to abnormal bleeding, it is not the most common cause in this age group.

 

Option D. Bleeding disorder: Bleeding disorders such as von Willebrand disease or hemophilia can cause menorrhagia but are less common compared to anovulation in adolescents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anovulation is the most common cause of menorrhagia in puberty.

questions.text: The ligament that maintains anteversion of the uterus during pregnancy is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Round ligament

 

Explanation:

 

The round ligament is responsible for maintaining the anteversion of the uterus, particularly during pregnancy. It consists of smooth muscle extensions of the uterine corpus and is the homologue of the gubernaculum testis. These ligaments arise from the lateral aspect of the corpus just below and anterior to the origin of the fallopian tubes, extend laterally to the pelvic sidewall, and enter the retroperitoneal space. They pass lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels before entering the inguinal canal through the internal inguinal ring and terminate in the subcutaneous tissue of the labia majora. During pregnancy, the round ligaments stretch to accommodate the enlarging uterus, helping to maintain its anteverted position. It maintains the angle of anteversion of 120°

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cardinal ligament: Also known as the transverse cervical ligament or Mackenrodt ligaments, these provide significant support to the uterus and cervix by attaching the lateral aspect of the uterus and cervix to the pelvic walls. However, they do not maintain anteversion.

 

Option C. Uterosacral ligament: These ligaments insert broadly into the posterior pelvic walls and sacrum and form the lateral boundaries of the cul-de-sac (Pouch of Douglas). They play a role in supporting the uterus but do not contribute to maintaining anteversion.

 

Option D. Pubocervical ligament: This ligament forms part of the supportive structure for the uterus and vagina, attaching them to the pubic bone. It provides anterior support but does not maintain the anteversion of the uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The round ligament is primarily responsible for maintaining the anteversion of the uterus, especially during pregnancy.

choices.text: Declare as complete abortion and follow-up in 15 days
Admit and observe
Follow-up with beta-HCG

questions.text: A patient with 6 weeks amenorrhea and a positive pregnancy test came with complaints of lower abdominal pain, moderate bleeding PV. She was hemodynamically stable. On ultrasound, there was no gestational sac in the uterus. Ovaries were normal and no free fluid in the pouch of Douglas. What is the next line of management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Follow-up with beta-HCG

 

The patient presents with symptoms that could indicate either an ectopic pregnancy or an early miscarriage. The absence of a gestational sac in the uterus on ultrasound at 6 weeks' gestation warrants further investigation to determine the location and viability of the pregnancy. The most appropriate next step is to follow up with serial beta-HCG levels.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Ectopic Pregnancy vs. Early Miscarriage: The differential diagnosis includes both ectopic pregnancy and early miscarriage.
  • Serial Beta-HCG Measurement: Beta-HCG levels typically double every 48-72 hours in a normal early intrauterine pregnancy. An abnormal rise or plateau in beta-HCG levels may indicate an ectopic pregnancy or a failing pregnancy.
  • Ultrasound Follow-up: In combination with beta-HCG monitoring, follow-up ultrasounds can help determine if a gestational sac becomes visible in the uterus or elsewhere.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Declare as complete abortion and follow-up in 15 days: Declaring a complete abortion without further investigation is premature and may miss an ectopic pregnancy, which can have serious complications.

 

Option B. Admit and observe: While observation is important, serial beta-HCG levels provide critical information that can guide further management decisions.

 

Option C. Diagnostic laparoscopy: This is an invasive procedure and is not the first step in stable patients without definitive evidence of ectopic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, a positive pregnancy test, and no gestational sac visible on ultrasound, the next step is to follow up with serial beta-HCG levels to differentiate between an early intrauterine pregnancy, an ectopic pregnancy, and a miscarriage.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg 356

choices.text: Do UPT and then give DMPA

questions.text: A female patient taking DMPA came 14 days late. What should be advised to her? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Give DMPA, no backup required

 

When a patient is up to 15 days late for a Depo-Provera (DMPA) injection, it is generally safe to administer the injection without additional contraceptive backup.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Do UPT and then give DMPA: Pregnancy testing is typically not required unless the delay exceeds 15 days.

 

Option B. DMPA + 7 days backup: Backup contraception is recommended if the delay exceeds 15 days.

 

Option C. DMPA from next cycle: There is no need to wait until the next cycle if the delay is within 15 days.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients receiving DMPA who are less than 15 days late for their injection, it can be administered without the need for additional contraceptive measures or delay.

questions.text: All of the following can be used in first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), except: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate

 

Explanation:

 

  • Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate:
    • This method is typically used for second-trimester abortions. It involves the instillation of ethacridine lactate into the extra-amniotic space to induce abortion. However, it is rarely used nowadays due to advancements in other safer and more effective methods.
  • Medical methods of first-trimester abortion:
    • Mifepristone + misoprostol: A combination of mifepristone (a progesterone receptor antagonist) and misoprostol (a prostaglandin analog) is a common and effective method for first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy.
  • Surgical methods of first-trimester abortion:
    • Manual vacuum aspiration: This is a safe and effective method for terminating a pregnancy in the first trimester.
    • Dilatation and curettage: Another surgical method used to evacuate the contents of the uterus in the first trimester.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone + misoprostol: Mifepristone + misoprostol is a commonly used combination for medical termination in the first trimester.

 

Option B. Manual vacuum aspiration: Manual vacuum aspiration is a standard procedure for first-trimester abortion.

 

Option C. Dilatation and evacuation: Dilatation and evacuation is another method used in the first trimester to terminate a pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate is not used for first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy (MTP).

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg364,369, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg203

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding audit in obstetrics? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Done before analysing outcomes

 

Clinical audit in obstetrics is a method performed to ensure that healthcare provisions are standardized and consistently improved in line with evidence-based practice. The purpose of an obstetrics audit is to analyze the current level of care and identify areas for improvement. Therefore, it is typically conducted after analyzing outcomes to assess and enhance the quality of care provided. This helps in determining whether the current practices are effective or if changes are needed to improve patient outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Improve treatment: This statement is true as clinical audits aim to improve treatment by identifying gaps in current practices and implementing evidence-based solutions to enhance patient care.

 

Option B. Fetal death rate analysis: This is also true. Clinical audits often include analyzing fetal death rates to understand the causes and contributing factors, which can lead to improved strategies to reduce such occurrences.

 

Option C. Improving hospital administration: This statement is correct. Audits can identify administrative issues that affect patient care, thereby helping to streamline processes and improve overall hospital administration and efficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clinical audits in obstetrics are conducted after analyzing outcomes to ensure that healthcare provisions are standardized and continuously improved based on evidence-based practices.

 

Ref: Dutta textbook of Obstetrics page728-729

questions.text: Which of the following is not used to treat PCOD? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tamoxifen

 

Explanation:

 

Tamoxifen is not commonly used in the treatment of Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD). Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) primarily used in the treatment and prevention of breast cancer.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Medical Management of PCOD:
    • OCP (Option D): Oral contraceptive pills regulate the menstrual cycle and hormones and are given to women who are not desirous of fertility to regularize their cycles.
    • Metformin (Option B): Metformin is an insulin sensitizer, which decreases hyperinsulinemia and improves fertility in patients with PCOD.
    • Ovulation Induction Drugs:
      • Clomiphene (Option A): Clomiphene citrate is commonly used to induce ovulation in women with infertility due to PCOD.
      • Letrozole: Letrozole, an aromatase inhibitor, is the drug of choice for ovulation induction in PCOD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clomiphene citrate: Clomiphene is an ovulation induction agent used in the treatment of infertility in women with PCOD.

 

Option B. Metformin: Metformin is used to decrease insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia in PCOD, which can help in regulating menstrual cycles and improving fertility.

 

Option D. OCP: Oral contraceptive pills are used to regulate menstrual cycles and manage hormonal imbalances in women with PCOD who do not seek to become pregnant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamoxifen is not typically used in the treatment of PCOD. Instead, treatments include oral contraceptive pills, metformin, and ovulation induction agents such as clomiphene and letrozole.
