Ref: William’s textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition. Pg 398 Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg470

choices.text: Elective C-section has no role in reducing incidence of brachial plexus injury
In a patient being planned for induction of labor, night dose of intermediate insulin is given as planned, and the morning dose is withheld
In active labor, if RBS <70 mg%, D5 is started at 100-150 ml/h till the RBS is >100 mg%
Capillary blood glucose monitoring levels are kept at fasting- 95 mg%; 1 h postprandial- 140 mg%; 2 h postprandial: 120 mg%

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding management of diabetes in pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Elective C-section has no role in reducing incidence of brachial plexus injury

 

Explanation:

 

  • False statement regarding management of diabetes in pregnancy is option A.
  • The Cesarean section is found to be protective against traumatic injuries such as brachial plexus injury, in macrosomic babies born to mothers with diabetes.
  • Elective LSCS is recommended when the estimated fetal weight is > 4.5kg in diabetic mothers to reduce the incidence of birth trauma

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. In a patient being planned for induction of labor, night dose of intermediate insulin is given as planned, and the morning dose is withheld: In a planned delivery, although the bedtime dose of intermediate-acting insulin is given, it is recommended that the morning dose must be withheld

 

Insulin Management for Labor Induction or Scheduled Cesarean Delivery

 

 

Option C. In active labor, if RBS <70 mg%, D5 is started at 100-150 ml/h till the RBS is >100 mg%: In active labor, if RBS (Random blood glucose) <70 mg%, D5 (5% dextrose) is started at 100-150 ml/h till the RBS is >100 mg%. Before initiation of labor, normal saline is used for iv infusion.

 

Option D. Capillary blood glucose monitoring levels are kept at fasting- 95 mg%; 1 h postprandial- 140 mg%; 2 h postprandial: 120 mg%: Self-monitoring of capillary blood glucose is advised in a pregnant woman diagnosed with diabetes. The glucose goals recommended are:

 

  • Fasting: 95 mg/dL
  • 1 h postprandial: 140 mg/dL
  • 2 h postprandial: 120 mg/dL

 

Educational Objective:

 

Elective C-section can reduce the incidence of brachial plexus injury in pregnancies complicated by diabetes, especially in cases of fetal macrosomia.

 

Ref: Page no 2807, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: The most potent natural estrogen is? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Estradiol

 

Estrogens play a crucial role in the development and regulation of the female reproductive system and secondary sexual characteristics. Among the natural estrogens, estradiol is the most potent. Estradiol is primarily produced by the ovaries and is the predominant estrogen during the reproductive years of a woman. It has the highest affinity for estrogen receptors, making it the most effective at eliciting estrogenic responses in the body.

 

Estrone, on the other hand, is the main estrogen found in postmenopausal women and is less potent than estradiol. Estriol is the weakest of the three natural estrogens and is predominantly produced during pregnancy. Conjugated equine estrogen is a mixture of estrogens derived from the urine of pregnant mares and is less potent than estradiol.

 

Therefore, estradiol is considered the most potent natural estrogen due to its strong affinity for estrogen receptors and its significant role in reproductive physiology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estrone: Although it is a natural estrogen, estrone is less potent than estradiol. It is primarily found in postmenopausal women and does not exert the same level of estrogenic activity as estradiol.

 

Option C. Estriol: This estrogen is the least potent of the natural estrogens and is mainly produced during pregnancy. It has a much lower affinity for estrogen receptors compared to estradiol.

 

Option D. Conjugated equine estrogen: This is a semi-synthetic mixture of estrogens obtained from horses. While it is used in hormone replacement therapy, its potency is lower than that of estradiol and it is not considered a single natural estrogen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Estradiol is the most potent natural estrogen, especially during a woman’s reproductive years, due to its high receptor affinity and significant physiological effects

choices.text: 10 to 12 weeks
8 to 10 weeks

questions.text: A primigravida presents to you in her early pregnancy with anemia. She is 7 weeks pregnant as seen on ultrasound. Her haemoglobin level is 9 g/dL. When should the iron supplements be started for her? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 8 to 10 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Prophylaxis for anemia in pregnancy is generally started at 14 weeks and continued for 180 days. However, the given question indicates that the patient has moderate anemia and requires immediate treatment. Among the provided options, the earliest time to start iron supplements is 8 to 10 weeks, making this the correct answer.

 

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat campaign, the severity of anemia is classified as follows:

 

  • Mild: 10-10.9 g%
  • Moderate: 7-9 g%
  • Severe: <7 g%

 

Testing and Treating Mild and Moderate Anemia

 

  • Mild anemia or moderate anemia: Give 2 tablets of iron.
  • Late presentation in pregnancy or inability to tolerate oral iron: Administer parenteral iron, such as iron carboxymaltose (FeCM).

 

Treating Severe Anemia

 

  • Hemoglobin < 7 g%: Administer iron carboxymaltose.
  • Late presentation in the third trimester with severe anemia or hemoglobin < 5 g%: Admit the patient for further management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10 to 12 weeks: While this is an earlier time frame than the standard prophylactic start, it is not as early as 8 to 10 weeks, which is necessary for moderate anemia.

 

Option C. After 14 weeks: This is the standard time for starting prophylactic iron supplements but is too late for a patient with moderate anemia who requires immediate treatment.

 

Option D. After 20 weeks: This is much too late for initiating treatment for anemia, especially for a patient with moderate anemia needing earlier intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of moderate anemia (Hb 7-9 g/dL) in early pregnancy, iron supplements should be started as early as 8 to 10 weeks to ensure timely treatment.

choices.text: Give progesterone and stop after 10 days for withdrawal bleeding

questions.text: A 25-year-old female came with complaints of 4 months amenorrhea. Her FSH and LH were elevated above the normal value, thyroid function tests were normal. Which is the next step in management? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Give progesterone and stop after 10 days for withdrawal bleeding

 

Explanation

 

  • Since LH and FSH are elevated above the normal value, the possibility of a pregnancy can be ruled out as FSH and LH levels fall to very low levels in pregnancy
  • The first step in evaluation of secondary amenorrhoea after ruling out pregnancy is to do a progesterone challenge test i.e. to see if she bleeds after a challenge of progesterone.
  • If she bleeds, the diagnosis is anovulation like in PCOS

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estimate serum estradiol values: Serum estradiol level measurement has no role in evaluation of secondary amenorrhoea

 

Option D. Do a urine pregnancy test: FSH levels in pregnancy are very very low so pregnancy is unlikely; otherwise the most common cause of secondary amenorrhoea is pregnancy

 

Option C. Check USG for Polycystic ovaries: This is done if the patient bleeds following progesterone withdrawal as it determines the cause of anovular cycles

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secondary amenorrhea is defined as a period of amenorrhoea of 6 months
  • Pregnancy needs to be ruled out
  • The most common cause of secondary amenorrhea after ruling out pregnancy is anovulation (PCOS) which can be determined by the progesterone withdrawal test

 

Ref: Page no 457, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: 1st trimester USG is the best assessment
Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period
In an IVF pregnancy, day of embryo transfer/day of fertilization is needed to calculate POG
Crown-rump length is the best measure of period of gestation in the first trimester

questions.text: Identify the wrong statement regarding the period of gestation calculation: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calculated from the last day of the last menstrual period

 

  • Gestational age or period of gestation (POG) refers to the duration of pregnancy calculated from the first day of last menstrual period
  • Calculating the EDD:
    • Normal duration of pregnancy: 280 days (40 weeks)
    • Calculating the EDD: Naegele’s formula. To the LMP (1st day of the last menstrual day)
      • Add 9 months + 7 days
      • Subtract 3 months and add 7 days
      • For IVF Pregnancies: add 38 weeks to the date of the embryo transfer
    • Dating the pregnancy: If discrepancy in dates/ unsure of LMP; the best way to determine the dating is by ULTRASOUND
      • 1st trimester CRL: most accurate (till 14 weeks)
      • BPD in the 2nd trimester

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1st trimester USG is the best assessment: Correct, because the 1st trimester USG provides the most accurate dating method.

 

Option C. In an IVF pregnancy, day of embryo transfer/day of fertilization is needed to calculate POG: Correct, because calculating gestational age in IVF pregnancies relies on the day of embryo transfer or fertilization.

 

Option D. Crown-rump length is the best measure of period of gestation in the first trimester: Correct, because CRL is the best measure for assessing the period of gestation in the first trimester.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gestational age is calculated from the first day of the last menstrual period (LMP), not the last day.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg, Dutta’s 108, 109, textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg127

choices.text: Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)
Functional ovarian cyst
Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for progression to borderline ovarian tumor? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nulliparity

 

Nulliparity is associated with a slightly increased risk of ovarian tumors, including borderline ovarian tumors, possibly due to uninterrupted ovulation and hormonal fluctuations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs: Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are known to reduce the risk of ovarian cancer.

 

Option B. Functional ovarian cyst: Functional ovarian cysts typically do not progress to ovarian tumors.

 

Option D. Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS): Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) has not been strongly linked with increased risk of borderline ovarian tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nulliparity is recognized as a risk factor for borderline ovarian tumors, highlighting the influence of reproductive factors on ovarian health.

choices.text: Colposcopy and biopsy
Follow-up after 6 months

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is diagnosed with carcinoma in situ (CIS) of the cervix and no obvious macroscopic growth. What is the next line of management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conization

 

  • Carcinoma in situ is Stage 0 Cancer.
  • It means it involves the entire thickness of the epithelium without invasion of the basement membrane.
  • This should be followed by a conization as the woman is 30 years old and conization will provide us with a biopsy specimen as well as be curative
  • If family is complete/ elderly patient, simple hysterectomy should be done

 

Treatment for Different stages of cervical cancer

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: While effective, it is more invasive and typically reserved for those who have completed childbearing or for older patients.

 

Option C. Colposcopy and biopsy: This is used for further evaluation but is not the definitive treatment for CIS when the diagnosis is already confirmed.

 

Option D. Follow-up after 6 months: Follow-up without intervention is not appropriate for CIS due to the risk of progression to invasive cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a young woman diagnosed with carcinoma in situ (CIS) of the cervix, conization is the recommended next step, providing both diagnostic and therapeutic benefits.

 

Ref: FIGO Revised Staging of Cervical Cancer, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th Edition, Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 8th edition page367,

questions.text: A female patient has a history of three miscarriages. Identify the investigation that was done from the image shown below? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hysterosalpingography

 

  • This is an image of a Hysterosalpingogram (HSG)
  • An HSG is used to
    • Delineate uterine anomalies.

Option A. Hysteroscopy: Hysteroscopy appears like this image. Using fluid media to distend the uterine cavity, a hysteroscope can visualize the inside of the uterine cavity.

 

 

Option B. Saline infusion sonography: Saline infusion sonography: This is an ultrasound-based investigation, wherein saline is injected in the uterine cavity and this helps detect intra-uterine space occupying lesions and appears like this:

 

 

Option D. Transvaginal ultrasound: This appears like this:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Hysterosalpingogram (HSG) is an X-ray procedure used to delineate uterine anomalies, identify endometrial cavity lesions, and assess tubal patency in cases of infertility.

 

Ref: Page no 588, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: HPV nonavalent vaccine is active against which of the following serotypes? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58

 

Explanation:

 

HPV Vaccines available are:

 

  1. Cervarix (Bivalent): 16, 18
  2. Gardasil (Quadrivalent): 6, 11, 16, 18
  3. Nonavalent: (Gardasil 9 or HPV9): 6, 11, 16, 18,31,33,45,52,58.
  4. Cervavac (India’s indigenous HPV vaccine): Quadrivalent: 6,11,16,18

 

Educational Objective:

 

HPV nonavalent vaccine is active against serotypes 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58.

 

Ref: https://www.who.int/news/item/20-12-2022-WHO-updates-recommendations-on-HPV-vaccination-schedule

choices.text: Minute volume decreases by 50%
Residual volume increases
Total lung capacity increases

questions.text: The correct statement regarding the physiological changes in the respiratory system in pregnancy? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) FRC decreases

 

Explanation:

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Minute volume decreases by 50%: This statement is incorrect. In fact, minute ventilation, which is the total volume of air inspired in a minute, increases by 40% during pregnancy due to an increase in tidal volume.

 

Option B. Residual volume increases: This statement is incorrect. Residual volume, which is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after maximal expiration, decreases by 20-25% during pregnancy.

 

Option D. Total lung capacity increases: This statement is incorrect. Total lung capacity, which is the maximum amount of air the lungs can hold, is either unaffected or slightly decreased (by about 5%) during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) decreases by approximately 22% during pregnancy due to the upward displacement of the diaphragm by the enlarging uterus.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg189, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 6

choices.text: Congenital heart defects

questions.text: On finding a congenital heart block in a fetus which of the following conditions would you evaluate for in the mother? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) SLE

 

Congenital heart block (CHB) in a fetus is often associated with maternal autoimmune conditions, particularly Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). This condition is related to the presence of maternal antibodies against the SS-A (Ro) or SS-B (La) antigens. These antibodies can cross the placenta and affect the fetal heart, leading to congenital heart block. Therefore, if a congenital heart block is detected in a fetus, it is essential to evaluate the mother for SLE.

 

Neonatal lupus erythematosus, a subtype of lupus erythematosus, is caused by the transplacental passage of these maternal antibodies. The most frequent clinical manifestations in the neonate include congenital heart block and cutaneous lesions. Fetal echocardiography is recommended between 18 and 26 weeks of gestation in pregnancies where these antibodies are present to monitor for congenital heart block.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. APLA syndrome: Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APLA) is associated with increased risks of miscarriages, intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD), and preterm births. However, it is not specifically associated with congenital heart block in the fetus.

 

Option B. Congenital heart defects: Women with certain congenital cardiac defects may have an increased chance of giving birth to children with similar defects, such as Marfan syndrome, aortic stenosis, ventricular septal defect (VSD), atrial septal defect (ASD), and coarctation of the aorta. However, these conditions are not directly linked to congenital heart block caused by maternal antibodies.

 

Option D. Hemolytic anemia: Hemolytic anemias, such as thalassemia, sickle cell anemia, and hereditary spherocytosis, are inherited conditions but are not associated with congenital heart block in the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital heart block (CHB) in a fetus is associated with maternal antibodies to SS-A (Ro) or SS-B (La), commonly seen in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE).

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 722

questions.text: MTP after 24 weeks is done for? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fetal anomaly

 

Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) after 24 weeks is permitted only in cases of substantial fetal anomalies. The MTP Act amendment of 2021 allows for this provision to ensure that pregnancies with severe and life-threatening fetal conditions can be terminated to prevent undue suffering for both the fetus and the parents.

 

The process involves a medical board, which is established at the district level or within medical colleges. This board typically includes a radiologist, a gynecologist, a pediatrician, and any relevant subspecialists depending on the nature of the anomaly. The board evaluates whether the fetal anomaly is substantial enough to warrant termination of the pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Minor: Termination for minors is allowed up to 24 weeks but not beyond.

 

Option C. Rape: Termination for pregnancies resulting from rape is allowed up to 24 weeks but not beyond.

 

Option D. Contraceptive failure: Termination due to contraceptive failure is allowed up to 20 weeks and, in some cases, up to 24 weeks but not beyond.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MTP beyond 24 weeks is allowed only for substantial fetal anomalies, as determined by a medical board, to ensure the safety and well-being of the mother and to address severe fetal conditions.

 

Indication for MTP -

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman underwent a workup for primary infertility. On hysterosalpingography, there was a bilateral cornual block. What is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hysteroscopy and laparoscopy-guided surgery

 

Cornual block, also known as proximal tubal obstruction, can be effectively managed with proximal tubal catheterization and cannulation, typically guided by hysteroscopy and laparoscopy. This method has about an 85% success rate in restoring tubal patency, making it the next logical step in management for a woman with a bilateral cornual block.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Cornual Block: Proximal tubal obstructions often require intervention to restore patency.
  • Hysteroscopy and Laparoscopy: These procedures allow for precise catheterization and cannulation to open the blocked tubes, leading to a high success rate.
  • Success Rate: Approximately 85% success in restoring tubal patency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuboplasty: While tuboplasty is an option for distal tubal occlusion, it is not the first-line treatment for cornual block.

 

Option C. Hydrotubation: This procedure involves flushing the tubes with fluid but is less effective for treating cornual block compared to hysteroscopy and laparoscopy-guided surgery. Success rates are poor (15-30 %)

 

Option D. In-vitro fertilization: IVF is typically considered when surgical interventions fail or are not suitable, particularly in women over 35 or those with severe tubal damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cornual block in a young woman with primary infertility should be managed with hysteroscopy and laparoscopy-guided proximal tubal catheterization and cannulation to restore tubal patency before considering more invasive options like IVF.

 

Ref: Page 1158, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th edition
